label: PresentTense with Yes Or No questions

questions.question: Do I exercise every day?
questions.answer: Yes, I do. / Yes, I exercise every day.

questions.question: Do I not exercise every day?
questions.answer: No, I don't. / No, I do not exercise every day.

questions.question: Do you visit your parents every month?
questions.answer: Yes, I do. / Yes, I visit my parents every month.

questions.question: Do you not visit your parents every month?
questions.answer: No, I don't. / No, I do not visit my parents every month.

questions.answer: No, he doesn't. / No, he does not celebrate his birthday every year.

label: Present Perfect continuous Tense with Wh questions

questions.question: Where has his book been staying for the last two weeks?
questions.answer: His book has been staying on the shelf for the last two weeks.

questions.question: Where has his book not been staying for the last two weeks?
questions.answer: His book has not been staying on the table for the last two weeks.

questions.question: What activity has she been enjoying since last summer?
questions.answer: She has been enjoying hiking since last summer.

questions.question: What activity has she not been enjoying since last summer?
questions.answer: She has not been enjoying running since last summer.

questions.question: Where has her cat been sleeping all day?
questions.answer: Her cat has been sleeping on the bed all day.

questions.question: Where has her cat not been sleeping all day?
questions.answer: Her cat has not been sleeping on the sofa all day.

questions.question: Where have you been parking your car recently?
questions.answer: I have been parking my car in the garage recently.

questions.question: Where have you not been parking your car recently?
questions.answer: I have not been parking my car on the street recently.

questions.question: Where has it been raining lately?
questions.answer: It has been raining in the city lately.

questions.question: Where has it not been raining lately?
questions.answer: It has not been raining in the desert lately.

questions.answer: Their books have been staying on the shelves for the past month.

questions.question: Where have their books not been staying for the past month?
questions.answer: Their books have not been staying on the table for the past month.

questions.answer: We have been enjoying hiking since last year.

questions.question: What activities have we not been enjoying since last year?
questions.answer: We have not been enjoying running since last year.

questions.answer: Our cats have been sleeping on the beds all day.

questions.question: Where have our cats not been sleeping all day?
questions.answer: Our cats have not been sleeping on the sofas all day.

questions.answer: We have been parking our cars in the garages recently.

questions.question: Where have you not been parking your cars recently?
questions.answer: We have not been parking our cars on the street recently.

questions.question: Where have they been eating dinner lately?
questions.answer: They have been eating dinner at restaurants lately.

questions.question: Where have they not been eating dinner lately?
questions.answer: They have not been eating dinner at home lately.

questions.question: Peter Piper picked a peck of pickled peppers. A peck of pickled peppers Peter Piper picked. If Peter Piper picked a peck of pickled peppers, Where’s the peck of pickled peppers Peter Piper picked?
questions.hint: Plosive sounds like /p/ and /k/, and /l/ sounds.

questions.question: Betty Botter bought some butter. But she said the butter’s bitter. If I put it in my batter, it will make my batter bitter. But a bit of better butter will make my batter better. So ‘twas better Betty Botter bought a bit of better butter
questions.hint: The /b/ sound, the /t/ sound, and the contrast between 'bitter' and 'better'

questions.question: How much wood would a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could chuck wood? He would chuck, he would, as much as he could, and chuck as much wood. As a woodchuck would if a woodchuck could chuck wood
questions.hint: The /w/ and /ch/ sounds, and the rhythm of repeated words

questions.question: She sells seashells by the seashore
I scream, you scream, we all scream for ice cream
questions.hint: Vowel sounds and the /s/ and /kr/ clusters.

questions.question: I saw Susie sitting in a shoeshine shop.Susie works in a shoeshine shop. Where she shines she sits, and where she sits she shines.
questions.hint: The /s/ and /ʃ/ sounds in quick succession

questions.question: You know New York, you need New York, you know you need unique New York
questions.hint: The /n/ and /j/ sounds, and the rhythm of repetition

questions.question: If a dog chews shoes, whose shoes does he choose?
Red lorry, yellow lorry
Which wristwatches are Swiss wristwatches?
questions.hint: The /w/ and /r/ sounds, and the challenging combination of 'wristwatches'

questions.question: Lesser leather never weathered wetter weather better
questions.hint: The /l/, /n/, and /w/ sounds, and the rhythm of similar-sounding words

questions.question: Good blood, bad blood
The sixth sick sheikh's sixth sheep's sick
questions.hint: /s/ and /ʃ/ sounds (e.g., 'sixth', 'sheikh's,' 'sheep's')  - #2 /k/ and /ks/ sounds (e.g., 'sick','sixth') #3 The /θ/ (th) sound (e.g., 'sixth'), #4 Vowel combinations that vary in length and pronunciation

questions.question: Enjoy cooking: She enjoys cooking Italian dishes.
Avoiding conflicts: He's very good at avoiding conflicts.
Consider swimming: You should consider swimming to stay fit.
Start exercising: I need to start exercising more regularly.
Finish reading: I plan to finish reading this book by the weekend.
Keep studying: If you keep studying, you'll do well on the test.
Love dancing: They love dancing to salsa music.
Hate waiting: I hate waiting in long lines.
Practice writing: You should practice writing every day to improve.
Imagine traveling: Can you imagine traveling around the world?
Mind working: Would you mind working late tonight?
Suggesting going: She's suggesting going to the new restaurant.
Admitting mistakes: Admitting mistakes is a sign of strength.
Recommend watching: I recommend watching this movie.
Regret leaving: She began to regret leaving her hometown.
Risk losing: By delaying, you risk losing the opportunity.
Keep trying: Even when it's tough, keep trying your best.
Discussing options: We spent hours discussing options for the project.
Delaying decisions: Delaying decisions can sometimes lead to missed opportunities.
Appreciate helping: I really appreciate you helping me out.
Finish painting: He needs to finish painting the fence before the rain starts.
Avoiding gossiping: She believes in avoiding gossiping about others.
Imagine exploring: Imagine exploring the uncharted regions of the Amazon.
Keep running: If you keep running at this pace, you'll break your record.
Start learning: It's never too late to start learning a new language.
Consider trying: You should consider trying a different approach.
Enjoy traveling: They enjoy traveling to exotic destinations.
Love singing: I love singing in the shower.
Hate cleaning: He really hates cleaning the bathroom.
Practice playing: You should practice playing the piano every day.
Being: Being punctual is important in a professional environment.
Having: Having a good attitude can make a big difference.
Doing: Doing your best is all that anyone can ask for.
Making: Making mistakes is a part of learning.
Getting: Getting enough sleep is crucial for your health.
Using: Using a planner helps me stay organized.
Seeing: Seeing is believing.
Saying: Saying 'thank you' shows appreciation.
Going: Going to the gym regularly improves your fitness.
Thinking: Thinking positively can change your outlook on life.
Wanting: Wanting more isn't always a bad thing.
Knowing: Knowing the answer gives you confidence.
Trying: Trying new foods can be an adventure.
Taking: Taking time to relax is important.
Giving: Giving back to the community feels rewarding.
Working: Working late isn't always the best solution.
Writing: Writing daily improves your skills.
Reading: Reading expands your knowledge.
Speaking: Speaking clearly helps others understand you.
Understanding: Understanding different perspectives is valuable.
